sp.p: Ile be chang'd in an instant, like a Scene, and then Ile fetch 'em to you. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sen. Trum.
sp.p: I, there goes one of his Swaggerers; I could ha' Swagger'd with him once— Oh! Colonel, you'r finely Poison'd, are you not? would I had the Poisoning o' you— where's my Son Dick? what ha' you done with him?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Mr. Truman.—

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: True me no more than I true you— come— Colonel you'r but a Swaggering— Ile ha' the Law to Swagger with you, that I will.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: First leave your Raging; though you should rage like Tamerlain at the Bull, 'twould do no good here.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p:
Do you call me names too? Ile have an Action o' Scandalum.
Well Colonel, since you provoke me, the Protector shall know what you are, and what you would have had me done for the King in the time of the last rising.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Mr. Truman, I took you for a Person of Honour, and a Friend to his Majesty; I little thought to hear you speak of betraying a Gentleman to the Protector.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Betraying? no Sir, I scorn it as much as you, but Ile let him know what you are, and so forth, an' you keep my Son from me.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Mr. Truman, if you'l but hear me patiently, I shall propose a thing that will, I hope, be good and acceptable both to your Son and you.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Say you so Sir? well; but I wo'nt be call'd Tamerlain.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: My Niece, not only by her wicked design to Poison me, but by Marrying her self without my consent this day to Puny, has (as you know very well, for you were a witness Sir to my Brother's will) lost all the right she had to a plentifull Portion. Aurelia shall have that and my Estate, (which now within few days I shall recover) after my Death; she's not I think Unhandsome, and all that know her will confess she wants no Wit; with these Qualities, and this Fortune, if your Son like her, (for though h'as injur'd me, Sir, I forget that, and attribute it only to the Enchantments of my Niece) I do so well approve both of his Birth and Parts, and of that Fortune, which you I think will please to make him, that I should be extremely glad of the Alliance.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Good Colonel, you were always a kind Neighbour and loving Friend to our Family, and so were we to you, and had respects for you; you know I would have had Dick marry your Niece, till you declar'd he should ha' no Portion with her.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: For that I had a particular reason, Sir; your Son's above in my House, shall I call him, Sir, that we may know his mind? I would not have him forc'd.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Pray send for him good Colonel; forc'd? no, Ile make him do't, Ile warrant you. Boys must not be their own choosers, Colonel, they must not 'ifaith, they have their Sympathies and Fiddle-come-saddles in their Brain, and know not what they would ha' themselves.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Why how now Lucia? how come you from your Chamber?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I hope you did not mean me a Prisoner, Sir, since now you'r satisfy'd sufficiently that you'r not Poison'd?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: I am not Dead, that's true. But I may thank Heaven, and a strong Constitution for't; you did your weak endeavours; however, for the honour of our Family, and for your Father's sake, Ile speak no more o' that, but I could wish, for the security of my Life hereafter, that you would go home to your Husband, for they say you'r marri'd Niece this day without my knowledge— Nay,— I'm content,— go home to him when you please, you shall ha' your thousand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Heark you, Colonel, she should not have a groat of e'em, not a groat; she can't recover't by Law, I know the Will.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I marry'd Sir? 'tis the first news I've heard of't.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Lucia goes to put on her Veil.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Nay, leave your pretty Jesuitical Love-tricks to salve an Oath; Mr. Truman, you may let your Son see her now.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: I Dick you may see her as much as you please; she's marri'd.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: Marri'd?

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: I marri'd, so I say, Marri'd this after-noon to Mr. Puny.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What do they mean?

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: And Dick I ha' got a Wife too for you, you shall ha' pretty Mrs. Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: Lucia marri'd?

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Her Father and I are agreed of all things; Heark you Dick, she has a brave Fortune now.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: Marri'd to Puny?

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: You shall have her presently.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: This after-noon?

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Come Dick; there's a Wife for you Dick.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: I wo'nt marry, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: What do you say Sir?

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: I wo' not marry Sir.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Get you out o' my sight you Rebel.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Nay, good Mr. Truman.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Ile ne're acknowledge him for my Son again; I tell you Colonel, he's always thus with his wo'nots and his Cannots.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: We ha' made short work on't; t'was a brave quick Parsonides; The little Skittish Philly got away from me I know not how, like an Eele out of a Basket.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Give him a little time Mr. Truman, he's troubl'd yet at my Nieces marriage, t'will over quickly.

sp.speaker: Tru. s.
sp.p: Give my Son time, Mr. Iolly? marry come up—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: What ha' you done already? you'r a sweet Husband indeed.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Oh! my little Pimp of honour! here, here's the five hundred Marigolds; hold thy hand Dido— yonder's my VVife, by Satan; how a Devil did that little Mephistophilus get hither before me?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: To her Puny; never conceal the mystery any longer, 'tis too good a Jest to be kept close.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: For your sake I will then, Colonel; Come prethee, Dick, be cheerfull.—

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: I beseech you,— Sir—

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p:
Look you there Colonel, now he should do what I
would have him, now hee's a beseeching— 'tis the proudest stubborn'st Coxcomb—

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: And now my noble Uncle— nay, never to Iolly. be angry at a Marriage i'the way of wit— My fair Egyptian Queen, come to thine Antony.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What would this rude fellow have?

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: I am drown'd in wonder!

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: 'Twas I, my dear Philoclea, that marri'd thee e'en row in the dark room, like an amorous Cat; you may remember the Damask Bed by a better Token of Two than a bow'd Philip and Mary.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I call Heaven to witness,
Which will protect and justifie the Innocent,
I understand not the least word he utters,
But as I took him always for a Fool,
I now do for a Mad-man.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: She's angry yet to have mistook her Man. 'Tis true, Sir, all that Mr. Puny says, I mean for to Iolly the Marriage, for the rest, she's best able to answer for her self.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: True, Cousin, then I see 'tis some conspiracy t'ensnare my Honor and my Innocence.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: The Parson, Mr. Soaker, that married 'em is still within.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: He's i'th' Buttery, shall I call him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: I, quickly.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: 'Tis the sight of me, no doubt, confounds her with a shame to confess any thing; It seems that sudden fit of raging lust, that brought her to my Chamber, could not rest till it was satisfi'd, it seems I know not what.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Mr. Soaker, did you marry my Niece this after-noon to Mr. Puny in the Matted Chamber?

sp.speaker: Soak.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I hope your Worship wo'nt be angry, Marriage, your Worship knows, is honorable.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hast thou no conscience neither?

div.head: Scene 12.
div.stage: Enter Widow, Tabitha, Cutter in a Puritanical habit.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Niece, go in a little, I'l come t' you presently and examine this matter further; Mr. Puny, lead in your wife for shame.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Villain, come not near me,
I'l sooner touch a Scorpion or a Viper. Exit.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: She's as humerous as a Bel-rope; she need not be so cholerique, I'm sure I behav'd my self like Propria quae maribus.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Come in with me, Mr. Puny, I'l teach you how you shall handle her. Exeunt Aur. Pun.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Mr. Truman, pray take your son home, and see how you can work upon him there; speak fairly to him.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Speak fairly to my son? I'l see him buried first.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: I mean perswade him—

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Oh! that's another matter; I will perswade him, Colonel, but if ever I speak fair to him till he mends his manners— Come along with me, Jack-sawce, come home. Exeunt Trum. sen. Trum. jun.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: I Sir, any whither.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: What's the matter, brother Colonel, are there any broils here?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Why, Sister, my Niece has married without my consent, and so it pleases, it e'en pleases Heaven to bestow her Estate upon me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, brother, there's a Blessing now already; If you had been a wicked Cavalier still she'd ha' done her duty, I warrant you, and defrauded you of the whole Estate; my brother Cutter here is grown the Heavenliest man o'the sudden, 'tis his work.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Sister Barebottle, I must not be called Cutter any more, that is a name of Cavalero darkness, the Devil was a Cutter from the beginning, my name is now Abednego, I had a Vision which whisper'd to me through a Key-hole, Go call thy self Abednego.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: The wonderful Vocation of some Vessels!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: It is a name that signifies Fiery Furnaces, and Tribulation, and Martyrdom, I know I am to suffer for the Truth.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Not as to death, Brother, if it be his will.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: As to death, Sister, but I shall gloriously return.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: What, Brother, after death? that were miraculous.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why the wonder of it is, that it is to be miraculous.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: But Miracles are ceas'd, Brother, in this wicked Age of Cavalerism.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: They are not ceas'd, Brother, nor shall they cease till the Monarchy be establish'd.

I say again I am to return, and to return upon a Purple Dromadary, which signifies Magistracy, with an Ax in my hand that is called Reformation, and I am to strike with that Ax upon the Gate of Westminster-hall, and cry, Down Babylon, and the Building called Westminster-hall is to run away and cast it self into the River, and then Major General Harrison is to come in Green sleeves from the North upon a Sky-colour'd Mule, which signifies heavenly Instruction.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Oh the Father! he's as full of Mysteries as an Egg is full of meat.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And he is to have a Trumpet in his mouth as big as a Steeple, and at the sounding of that Trumpet all the Churches in London are to fall down.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: O strange, what times shall we see here in poor England!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And then Venner shall march up to us from the West in the figure of a Wave of the Sea, holding in his hand a Ship that shall be call'd the Ark of the Reform'd.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: But when must this be, Brother Abednego?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why all these things are to be when the Cat of the North has o're-come the Lion of the South, and when the Mouse of the West has slain the Elephant of the East. I do hear a silent Voice within me, that bids me rise up presently and declare these things to the Congregation of the Lovely in Coleman-street. Tabitha, Tabitha, Tabitha, I call thee thrice, come along with me, Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: There was something of this, as I remember, in my last Vision of Horns the other day. Holy man! I follow thee; farewell, forsooth, Mother, till anon.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Come, let's go in too, Sister. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Truman Iunior.
sp.l: WHat shall I think hence-forth of Woman-kind?
When I know Lucia was the best of it,
And see her what she is? What are they made of?
Their Love, their Faith, their Souls enslav'd to passion!
Nothing at their Command beside their Tears,
And we, vain men, whom such Heat-drops deceive!
Hereafter I will set my self at Liberty,
And if I sigh or grieve, it shall not be
For Love of One, but Pity of all the Sex.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.l: Ha! she will not let me see her sure;
If ever, Lucia, a Veil befitted thee,
'Tis now, that thou maist hide thy guilty blushes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: If all their malice yet
Have not prevail'd on Truman's Constancy,
They'l miss their wicked end, and I shall live still.
I'l go and speak to him.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: Forbear, Lucia, for I have made a second Oath, which I shall keep, I hope, with lesser trouble, never to see thy face more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You were wont, Sir,
To say, you could not live without the sight of't.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: I; 'twas a good one then.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Has one day spoil'd it?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.p: O yes, more than a hundred years of time, made as much more by sorrow, and by sickness, could e're have done.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Pray hear me, Truman:
For never innocent Maid was wrong'd as I am;
Believe what I shall say to you, and confirm
By all the holiest Vows that can bind Souls.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: I have believ'd those Female tricks too long;
I know thou canst speak winningly, but thy Words
Are not what Nature meant them, thy Minds Picture;
I'l believe now what represents it better,
Thine own Hand, and the proof of mine own Eyes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I know not what you mean; believe my Tears.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: They'r idle empty Bubbles.
Rais'd by the Agitation of thy Passions,
And hollow as thy heart; there is no weight in 'em.
Go thou once, Lucia; Farewel,
Thou that wer't dearer to me once, than all
The outward things of all the World beside,
Or my own Soul within me, farewel for ever;
Go to thine Husband, and love him better than
Thou didst thy Lover.
I ne're will see the more, nor shall, I fear,
Ere see my self again.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Here me but once. kneels.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: No, 'tis enough; Heaven hear thee when thou kneel'st to it. Exit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Will he? he's gone; now all the world has left me, rises.
And I am desolately miserable;
'Tis done unkindly, most unkindly, Truman.
Had a blest Angel come to me and said
That thou wert false, I should have sworn it li'd,
And thought that rather faln than thee.
Go, dear, false man, go seek out a new Mistris;
But when you ha' talk'd, and lov'd, and vow'd, and sworn
A little while, take heed of using her
As you do me; no, may your love to her
Be such as mine to you, which all thy injuries
Shall never change, nor death it self abolish.
May she be worthier of your bed than I,
And when the happy course of many years
Shall make you appear old to all but her,
May you in the fair Glass of your fresh Issue
See your own youth again; but I would have 'em
True in their Loves, and kill no innocent Maids;
For me it is no matter; when I'm dead,
My busie soul shall flutter still about him,
'Twill not be else in Heaven; it shall watch
Over his sleeps, and drive away all dreams
That come not with a soft and downy wing;
If any dangers threaten, it shall becken
And call his spirit away, till they be past,
And be more diligent than his Guardian Angel;
And when just Heaven, as I'm assur'd it will,
Shall clear my Honor and my Innocence,
He'l sigh, I know, and pity my misfortunes,
And blame himself, and curse my false Accusers,
And weep upon my Grave
For my wrong'd Virtue, and mistaken Truth,
And unjust Death, I ask no more. Exit.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.l: 'Twas barbarously done to leave her so;
Kneeling and weeping to me; 'twas inhuman;
I'l back and take my leave more civilly,
So as befits one who was once her Worshipper. Goes over the Stage, and comes back.
She's gone; why let her go; I feel her still;
I feel the root of her, labouring within
To sprout afresh, but I will pluck it up,
Or tear my heart with 't.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: He's there, Sir, pray let him now resolve you positively what he means to do.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.l: What he means to do, Colonel? that were fine
'Ifaith; if he be my son he shall mean nothing;
Boys must not have their meanings, Colonel:
Let him mean what I mean with a Wennion.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: I shall be prest, I see, by 'em, upon the hateful Subject of a Marriage;
And to fill up the measure of Affliction,
Now I have lost that which I lov'd, compell'd
To take that which I hate.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: I wil not be troubled, Colonel, with his meanings, if he do not marry her this very evening (for I'le ha' none of his Flim-flams and his May-be's) I'l send for my son Tom from St. Iohn's College (he's a pretty Scholar I can tell you, Colonel, I have heard him syllogize it with Mr. Soaker in Mood and Figure) and settle my Estate upon him with her; if he have his Meanings too▪ and his Sympathies, I'l disinherit 'em both, and marry the Maid my self, if she can like me, I have one Tooth yet left, Colonel, and that's a Colt's one.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: Did I submit to lose the sight of Lucia
Onely to save my unfortunate Inheritance,
And can there be impos'd a harder Article
For me to boggle at?
Would I had been born some wretched Peasants son,
And never known what Love or Riches were.
Ha— I'l marry her— why should I not? if I
Must marry some body,
And hold my Estate by such a slavish Tenure,
Why not her as well as any else?
All Women are alike I see by Lucia,
'Tis but resolving to be miserable,
And that is resolv'd for me by my Destiny.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.l: Well, try him pray, but do it kindly, Sir,
And artificially.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: I warrant you; Dick, I'l ha' you marry Mrs. Aurelia to night.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: To night? the warning's short, Sir, and it may be—

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Why look you, Colonel, he's at's old look, he's at's May-bees again.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: I know not, Sir—

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: I, and his Know-nots, you shall have him at his Wo' nots presently; Sirra— I will have you know, Sir—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Nay, good Mr. Truman— you know not yet what answer he intends to make you.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: Be pleas'd, Sir, to consider—

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Look you, Sir, I must consider now, he upbraids his father with the want of consideration, like a Varlet as he is.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: What shall I do? why should not I do any thing,
Since all things are indifferent?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: I beseech you, Mr. Truman, have but a little patience— Your father, Sir, desires to know—

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: I do not desire him, Colonel, nor never will desire him, I command him upon the duty of a Child—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Whether you can dispose your self to love and marry my daughter Aurelia, and if you can, for several reasons we desire it may be presently consummated.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: Out with it, stubborn Tongue;
I shall obey my father, Sir, in all things.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Ha! what dee' you say, Sir?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: This old testy Fool is angry, I think, to have no more occasion given him of being so.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: I shall obey you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: You speak, Sir, like a vertuous Gentleman, the same obedience and resignation, to a father's will, I found in my Aurelia, and where two such persons meet, the issue cannot chuse but be successful.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Ah Dick, my son Dick, he was always the best natur'd Boy— he was like his father in that— he makes me weep with tenderness, like an old fool as I am— Thou shalt have all my Estate, Dick, I'l put my self to a pension rather than thou shalt want— go spruse up thy self a little presently, thou art not merry 'Ifaith, Dick, prethee be merry, Dick, and fetch fine Mrs. Aurelia presently to the little Church behind the Colonel's Garden, Mr. Soaker shall be there immediately and wait for you at the Porch (we'l have it instantly, Colonel, done, lest the young fool should relapse) come, dear Dick, let's go cheerily on with the business.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.p: What have I said? what am I doing? the best is, it is no matter what I say or do.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: I'l see Aurelia shall be ready, and all things on my part within this half hour.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Good, honest, noble Colonel, let me shake you by the hand. Come, dear Dick, we lose time. Exeunt.

div.head: Scene 5. Enter Cutter, Tabitha, a Boy.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: And the Vision told me, sister Tabitha, that this same day, the first of the seventh month, in the year of Grace 1658. and of Revelation, and Confusion of Carnal Monarchies the tenth, that we two, who are both holy Vessels, should by an holy Man be joyned together in the holy Bond of sanctifi'd Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Tab:
sp.p: I brother Abednego, but our friends consents—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Heaven is our friend, and, Sister, Heaven puts this into our thoughts; it is, no doubt, for propagation of the great Mystery; there shall arise from our two bodies, a great Confounder of Gogmagog, who shall be called the Pestle of Antichrist, and his children shall inherit the Grapes of Canaan.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: My mother will be angry, I'm afraid.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Your Mother will rejoyce, the Vision says so, sister, the Vision says your Mother will rejoyce; how will it rejoyce her righteous heart to see you, Tabitha, riding behind me upon the Purple Dromedary? I would not for the world that you should do it, but that we are commanded from above; for to do things without the aforesaid Command is like unto the building of a Fire without the Bottom-cake.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I I, that it is, he knows.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Now to confirm to you the truth of this Vision, there is to meet us at a zealous Shoomaker's habitation hard by here, by the command of a Vision too, our Brother Zephaniah Fat's, an Opener of Revelations to the Worthy in Mary White-chapel, and he is the chosen Vessel to joyn our hands.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I would my Mother knew't; but if that holy man come too by a Vision, I shall have grace, I hope, not to resist.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Sister, let me speak one word of Instruction to yonder Babe.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Oh how my bowels yern!

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Sirra, is my little Doctor already staying for me at Tom Underleather my Shoomaker's house?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, but he's in so strange a Habit, that Mr. Underleather's Boy Franck and I were ready to die with laughing at him.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Oh so much the better; go you little piece of a Rogue and get every thing ready against I come back. Exit Boy. Sister, that Babe you saw me speaking to is predestinated to Spiritual Mightiness, and is to be restorer of the Mystical Tribe of Gad—

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Oh the Wonderous— but, Brother Abednego, will you not pronounce this Evening tide before the Congregation of the Spotless in Coleman-street?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: The will of the latter Vision is to be fulfilled first, as a Preparatory Vision; let us not make the Messenger of Mystery, who is sent by a Vision so far as from Mary White-chapel for our sakes, to stay too long from his lawful Vocation of Basket-making. Come, Sister Tabitha.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Hei, ho! but I will not resist. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Mr. Puny, since you threaten me, I tell you plainly I think my Niece has undone her self by marrying thee, for though thou hast a fair Estate at present, I'm hainously mistaken if thou beest not cheated of it all within these three years by such Rabbit-suckers as these, that keep thee company, and like lying sons o' the Devil as they are, cry thee up for a Wit, when there's nothing so unlike, no not any of thy own Similitudes, thy odious Comparisons.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: The Colonel's raging mad, like a Baker in the Subburbs, when his Oven's over-heated.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Good, very good i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: I, that was one of 'em; as for her Portion, I thought to ha' given her a thousand pounds, but—

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: O magnanimous Colonel! what a Portion for a Toothpick-maker's daughter!

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Good, shoot him thick with similies like Hail-shot.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: But now thou shalt not have a groat with her.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p:
What not a poor old Harry-Groat that looks as thin as a Poet's Cloak? But however, my noble Mountain hearted Uncle, I ha' made her Maiden-head a Crack'd Groat already, and if I ha' nothing more from her, she shall ha' nothing more from me; no, she
shall foot Stokins in a Stall for me, or make Childrens Caps in a Garret fifteen stories high.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: For that matter (for though thou speak'st no sense I guess thy brutish meaning) the Law will allow her honorable Alimony out o' your Foolship's Fortune.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: And the Law will allow me her Portion too, good Colonel Uncle, you'r not too big to be brought into Westminster-hall; nay, Captain, his Niece uses me worse too, she will not let me touch the Nail of her little finger, and rails at me like a Flounder-mouth'd Fish-woman with a face like Billingsgate.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: What flesh can support such an affected Widgen, who ha's not a design to cheat him of something as that Vermin ha's? well, I shall be able to Live now I hope as befits a Gentleman, and therefore I'le endure the company of Fopps and Knaves no longer.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Come Colonel, let's go in, and dispute the difference conscienciously over a Bottle o' Sack.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: I keep no Tavern, Worm; or if I did, thy whole Estate would hardly reach to a Gill.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Colonel, thou art grown Unkind, and art Drunk this afternoon without me.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Without thee, Buffoon? why I tell thee, thou shall never shew that Odd, Pimping, Cheating face o' thine within my Doors agen, I'le turn away any man o' mine that shall disparage himself to drink with such a fellow as thou art.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: As I? why what am I? pray? Mighty Colonel!

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Thou art or hast been every thing that's ill, there is no Scandalous way of Living, no Vocation of the Devil, that thou hast not set up in at one time or other; Fortune ha's Whip'd thee about through all her streets; Thou 'rt one that Lives like a Raven, by Providence and Rapin; now thou 'rt feeding upon that raw young fellow, and doest Devour and Kaw him; thou 'rt one that if thou should'st by chance go to Bed sober, would'st write it down in thy Almanack, for an Unlucky day; sleep is not the Image of Death to thee, unless thou bee'st Dead drunk; Thou art— I know not what— thou'rt any thing, and shall be to me herafter nothing.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: This Colonel pisses Vinegar to day.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: This is uncivil Language Colonel to an old Camerade, and one of your own party.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: My Comrade? o' my party thou? or any but the party of the Pick-purses!

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: This bouncing Bear of a Colonel will break the back o' my little Whelp of a Captain, unless I take him off; come away Captain, I'le firk his back with two Bum-baylies, till he spew up every Stiver of her Portion.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Fare-ye-well, Gentlemen, come not near these Doors if you love your own Leather, I'l ha' my Scullions batter you with Bones and Turneps, and the Maids drown you with Piss-pots, if you do but approach the Windows; these are sawcy Knaves indeed, to come to me for Pounds and Portions. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Poverty, the Pox, an ill Wife, and the Devil go with thee, Colonel.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I vex'd him to the Gills, Worm, when I put that bitter Bob o' the Baker upon him.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I? i'st e'n so? not come to your House? by Iove I'l turn him out of it himself by a trick that I have.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Pish! thou talk'st as Ravingly as a Costermonger in a Feaver.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I'l do't by Iove.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: How, prethee, Captain? what does thy Pericranium mean?

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: Why here I ha't, by Iove; I'm ravish'd with the fancy of it; let me see— let me see— his Brother went seven years ago to Guiny.—

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I, but the Merchants say he's Dead long since, and gon to the Blackamores below.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: The more Knaves they; he Lives, and I'm the man.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! thou talk'st like a Sowc'd Hoggs-face.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: I knew him very well, and am pretty like him, liker than any of your Similitudes, Puny; by long Conversation with him, and the Colonel, I know all passages betwixt 'em; and what his Humor and his Estate was, much better than he himself, when he was Alive; he was a Stranger thing than any Monster in Afrique where he Traded.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: How! prethee Captain? I love these Odd fantastical things as an Alderman loves Lobsters.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: Why, you must know, he had quite lost his memory, totally, and yet thought himself an able man for business, and that he did himself all that was done by his man Iohn, who went always along with him; like a Dog with a Blind man.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Sublimely fantastical

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: He carry'd a Scrowl about him of Memorandums, even of his Daughters and his Brothers names, and where his House stood; for as I told you, he remembred nothing; and where his Scrowl failed, Iohn was his remembrancer, we were wont to call him Remembrancer Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Rarely exotique! I'l Act that apple Iohn, never was such a Iohn as I; not Iohn o' Gant, or Iohn o' Nokes, I will turn Remembrancer Iohn, as round as a Wedding Ring, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: Well said! but you must lay aside conceits for a while, and remote fancies. I'l teach you his humor instantly; now will I and my man Iohn swarthy our faces over as if that Country's heat had made 'em so, (which will Disguise us sufficiently) and attire our selves in some strange Habits o' those Parts, (I know not how yet, but we shall see it in Speed's Mapps) and come and take Possession of our House and Estate.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Dear Ovid, let's about thy Metamorphosis.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: 'Twill be discover'd perhaps at last, but however, for the present 'twill break off his match with the Widdow, (which makes him so Proud now) and therefore it must be done in the twinkling of an Eye, for they say he's to marry her this Night; if all fail, 'twill be at least a merry 'bout for an hour, and a mask to the Wedding.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Quick, dear Rogue! quick as Precipitation.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: I know where we can ha' Cloaths, hard by here; give me ten Pounds to hire 'em, and come away, but of all things, man Iohn, take heed of being witty.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I, that's the Devil on't; well, go; I'l follow you behind like a long Rapier. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: If they would allow me but a little time, I could play such a trick with Mr. Truman, as should smart sorely for the rest of his Life, and be reveng'd abundantly on my Cozen, for getting of him from me, when I was such a foolish Girl three year ago as to be in Love with him.
But they would have us marri'd instantly, The Parson stays for us at Church. I know not what to do— all must out— Odds my life he's coming to fetch me here to Church already.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: I must go through with it now; I'l marry her,
And live with her according to the forms,
But I will never touch her as a Woman.
She stays for me— Madam—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: I cannot out with it— Madam.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sir—

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: Must we go marry, Madam?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Our friends will have it so, it seems.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Why will you marry me? what is there in me
That can deserve your liking? I shall be
The most untoward and ill-favour'd Husband
That ever took a melting Maid t' his Bed;
The faculties of my Soul are all untuned,
And every Glory of my Springing youth
Is faln into a strange and suddain Winter,
You cannot Love me sure.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Not to Distraction, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: No, nor I you; why should we marry then?
It were a folly, were it not, Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why they say, 'tis the best marriage, when like is Joyn'd to like; now we shall make a very even match, for neither you Love me, nor I Love you, and 'tis to be hop'd we may get Children that will Love neither of us.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Nay, by my soul I love you, but alas,
Not in that way that Husbands should their Wives;
I cannot Toy, nor Kiss, nor do I know not what,
And yet I was a Lover, as true a Lover—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Alack a day!

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: 'Twas then, (me-thoughts) the only happiness
To sit and talk, and look upon my Mistriss,
Or if she was not by, to think upon her;
Then every Morning, next to my Devotion,
Nay often too (forgive me Heaven) before it,
She slipt into my fancy, and I took it
As a good Omen for the following day;
It was a pretty foolish kind of Life,
An honest, harmless Vanity; but now
The fairest Face moves me no more, than Snow
Or Lillies when I see 'em, and pass by;
And I as soon should deeply fall in Love
With the fresh Scarlet of an Eastern Cloud,
As the Red Lips and Cheeks of any Woman;
I do confess, Aurelia, thou art Fair,
And very Witty, and (I think) Well-natur'd,
But thou'rt a Woman still.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: The sight of you Sir,
Makes me not repent at all my being so.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: And prethee now, Aurelia, tell me truly,
Are any Women constant in their Vows?
Can they continue a whole Moneth, a Week,
And never change their faith? Oh! if they could,
They would be excellent things; nay ne're dissemble;
Are not their Lusts unruly, and to them
Such Tyrants as their Beauties are to us?
Are their tears true, and solid when they weep?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Sure Mr. Truman you ha'nt slept of late,
If we should be marry'd to Night, what would you do for Sleep?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Why? do not marry'd people sleep o' Nights?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Yes! yes! alas good innocence.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: They have a scurvy Life on't if they don't;
But wee'l not Live as other people do,
Wee'l find out some new handsome way of Love,
Some way of Love that few shall imitate,
Yet all admire; for 'tis a sordid thing,
That Lust should dare t' insinuate it self
Into the Marriage-bed; wee'l get no Children,
The worst of Men and Women can do that;
Besides too, if our Issue should be Female,
They would all Learn to flatter and dissemble,
They would deceive with Promises and Vows
Some simple men, and then prove False and Kill 'em,
Would they not do't, Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I, any thing Mr. Truman; but what shall we do Sir, when we are marry'd, pray?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Why! wee'l live very Lovingly together,
Sometimes wee'l sit and talk of excellent things,
And laugh at all the Nonsence of the world;
Sometimes wee'l walk together,
Sometimes wee'l read, and sometimes eat, and sometimes sleep;
And sometimes pray, and then at last, wee'l dye,
And go to Heaven together; 'twill be rare!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: We may do all this (me-thinks) and never marry for the matter.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: 'Tis true, we may so!
But since our Parents are resolv'd upon it,
In such a Circumstance let 'em have their humor.
My father sent me in to Complement,
And keep a Prating here, and play the Fool;
I cannot do't, what should I say, Aurelia?
What do they use to say?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: I believe you knew Sir, when you Woo'd my Cozen.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: I, but those Days are past; they'r go for ever,
And nothing else, but Nights are to succeed 'em;
Gone like the faith and truth of Women kind,
And never to be seen again! O Lucia!
Thou wast a woundrous Angel in those days of thy blest state of Innocence.
There was a Cheek! a Fore-head! and an Eye!—
Did you observe her Eye, Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: O yes Sir! there were very pretty Babies in't.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: It was as glorious as the Eye of Heaven;
Like the souls Eye it peirc'd through every thing;
And then her Hands— her Hands of Liquid Ivory!
Did she but touch her Lute (the pleasing'st Harmony then upon Earth when she her self was silent)
The subtil motion of her Flying fingers
Taught Musique a New art, to take the Sight, as well as Ear.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I, Sir, I! you'd best go look her out, and marry her, she has but one Husband yet.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Nay, prethee, good Aurelia be not angry,
For I will never Love or See her more.
I do not say she was more Fair than thou art,
Yet if I did? No, but I wo'not say so!
sp.p: Only allow me this one short last remembrance of one I lov'd so long. And now I think on't, I'l beg a favour of you, you will Laugh at me I know, when you have heard it, but prethee grant it; 'tis that you would be Veil'd, as Lucia was of late, for this one day; I would fain marry thee so; 'Tis an odd foolish fancy, I confess, But Love and Grief may be allow'd sometimes A little Innocent folly.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Good! this Fool will help me I see to cheat himself;
At a dead lift, a little hint will serve me.
I'l do't for him to the Life.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Will you Aurelia?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: That's but a small Compliance; you'l ha' power anon to Command me greater things.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: We shall be marry'd very privately;
None but our selves; and that's e'en best, Aurelia.
Why do I stick here at a Fatal step
That must be made? Aurelia, are you ready?
The Minister stays for us.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I'l but go in and take my Veil, as you Command me Sir; Walk but a few turns in the Garden, in less than half an hour I'l come to you, ha, ha, ha! Exit.

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: I go, I am Condemn'd, and must Obey;
The Executioner stays for me at Church.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: So, I have her at last, and honest Ioseph Knock-down married us, me-thinks, with convenient brevity; I have some hold now upon my Estate again (though she, I confess, be a clog upon it worse than a Mort-gage) that, my good Neighbour Barebottle left wholly to his wife; almost all the rest of the Incomes upon his seeking, go to his daughter Tabitha, whom Cutter has got by this time, and promises me to live like an honest Gentleman hereafter; now he may do so comfortably and merrily. She marri'd me thus suddenly, like a good Houswife, purely to save charges; however though, we'l have a good Supper for her, and her eating Tribe; Will, is the Cook a doing according to my directions?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, he's very hard at his business; he's swearing and cursing in the Kitchin, that your Worship may hear him hither, he'l fright my new old Mistris out of the house.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: 'Tis such an over-roasted coxcomb— bid him be sure to season well the Venison that came in luckily to day.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Troth, Sir, I dare not speak to him now, unless I should put on your Worship's Armour that lies hid in the Barel below; he'd like to ha' spitted me just now, like a Goose as I was, for telling him he look'd like the Ox that's roasted whole in St. Iames's Fair. Who's there?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: See who's at door. I shall ha' some plundred Plate, I hope, to entertain my friends with, when we come to visit the Truncks with Iron hoops; who is't?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Nay, Heaven knows, Sir; two Fiends, I think, to take away the Cook for swearing. They ha' thrust in after me.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter Worm and Puny disguised like the Merchant and John.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: They'l hardly know us at first in these forein habits.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I Sir, and as the Sun has us'd us in those hot Countries.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Why, this is my old house here, Iohn; ha, ha! little thought I to see my old house upon Tower-hill again. Where's my brother Iolly?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: They call me Colonel Iolly.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Ha! let me see, A burly man of a Looks on his Note. moderate stature— a beard a little greyish— ha! a quick Eye, and a Nose inclining to red—

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Nay, 'tis my Master's Worship, Sir, would we were no more alter'd since our Travels.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: It agrees very well— Save you good brother, you little thought to see me here again, though I dare say you wish'd it; stay, let me see, how many years, Iohn, is't since we went from hence?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: 'Tis now seven years, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Seven? me-thinks I was here but yesterday, how the what deye-call-it-runs? how do you call it?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: The Time, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I, I, the time, Iohn; what was I saying? I was telling you, brother, that I had quite forgot you; was I not telling him so, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Faith we'r both quits then; I'l swear I ha' forgot you; why you were dead five years ago.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Was I? I ha' quite forgot it; Iohn, was I dead five years ago? my memory fails me very much of late.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: We were worse than dead, Sir, we were taken by a barbarous Nation, and there made slaves; Iohn, quoth he? I was poor Iohn I'm sure; they kept us three whole years with nothing but Water and Acorns, till we look'd like Wicker bottles.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What, Sirrah, did your Master look like? I'l teach you to say your Master look'd like what de-ye-call'ums.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Where did they take you prisoners?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Nay, ask Iohn, he can tell you I warrant you; 'twas in— tell him, Iohn, where it was.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: In Guiny.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: By what Country-men were you taken?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Why they were called— I ha' forgot what they call'em, 'twas an odd kind o' name, but Iohn can tell you.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Who I, Sir? do you think I can remember all things?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: 'Tis i' my Book here I remember well. Name any Nation under the Sun.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I know the name, Sir, well enough; but I onely try'd my Master's memory, 'Twas the Tartarians.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I, I, those were the men.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: How, Iohn? why all the world man lies betwixt 'em, they live up in the North.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: The North?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: I the very North, Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: That's true indeed, but these were another Nation of Tartarians that liv'd in the South, they came antiently from the others.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: How got you from 'em, Iohn, at last?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Why faith, Sir, by a Ladies means, who, to tell you the truth, fell in love with me; my Master has it all in his Book, 'tis a brave story.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: In what Ship came you back?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: A plague of't, that question will be our ruine.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: What Ship? 'twas call'd a thing that swims, what dee you call't?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: The Mermaid?

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: No, no, let me see.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: The Triton?

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: No, no, a thing that in the water does— it swims in the water—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: What is't? the Dolphin?

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: No, no, I ha' quite forgot the name on't, but 'tis no matter, it swims—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: What say you, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I, Sir, my Master knows well enough; you cann't conceive the misery we endur'd, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Well, Brother, I'l but ask you one question more, where did you leave your Will?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: ‛ Life, now he's pos'd again— we shall never carry't through.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: I'l tell you presently, Brother— let me see, Reads in his Scrowl. Memorandums about my Will; left to my Brother the whole charge of my Estate— hum— hum— five thousand pounds— hum— What did you ask me, brother?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: In what place you left your Will?

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: I that was it indeed—, that was the very thing you ask'd me; what a treacherous memory have I? my memory is so short—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: This is no Answer to my Question yet.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed; what was your Question, brother?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Where you left your Will?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Good Lord, that I should forget you ask'd me that! I had forgot it, i'faith law that I had, you'l pardon, I hope, my Infirmity, for I alas— alas— I ha' forgot what I was going to say to you, but I was saying something, that I was.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Well, Gentlemen, I'm now in haste, walk but a while into the Parlour there, I'l come to you presently.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But where's my daughter—

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Lucia, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I, Lucia— put me in mind to ask for her (a plague o' your Tartarians.)

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: And o'your What dee-ye-call-'ems.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: ‛ Life, Tartarians!

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: If these be Rogues, (as Rogues they seem to be) I will so exercise my Rogues, the tyranny of a new Beadle over a Beggar shall be nothing to't; what think'st thou of 'em, Will?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Faith, Sir, I know not— h'as just my Masters Nose and Upper-lip; but if you think it be not he, Sir, I'l beat 'em worse than the Tartarians did.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: No, let's try 'em first— trick for trick— Thou were wont to be a precious Knave, and a great Actor too, a very Roscius; did'st not thou play once the Clown in Musidorus?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: No, but I plaid the Bear, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: The Bear! why that's as good a Part; thou 'rt an Actor then I'l warrant thee, the Bears a well-penn'd Part, and you remember my Brother's humor, don't you? They have almost hit it.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: I, Sir, I knew the shortness of his memory, he would always forget to pay me my Wages, till he was put in mind of't.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Well said, I'l dress thee within, and all the Servants shall acknowledge thee, you conceive the Design— be confident, and thou cast not miss; but who shall do trusty Iohn?

sp.speaker: Will:
sp.p: Oh, Ralph the Butler, Sir, 's an excellent try'd Actor, he play'd a King once; I ha' heard him speak a Play ex tempore in the Butteries.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p:
O excellent Ralph! incomparable Ralph against the world!
Come away, VVilliam, I'l give you instructions within, it must be done in a moment. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! this is the best Plot o' yours, dear Madam, to marry me to Mr. Truman in a Veil instead of your self; I cann't chuse but laugh at the very conceit of't; 'twill make excellent sport: My Mistris will be so mad when she knows that I have got her Servant from her, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Well, are you ready? Veil your self all over, and never speak one word to him, what ever he says, (he'l ha' no mind to talk much) but give him your hand, and go along with him to Church; and when you come to, I take thee— mumble it over that he may n't distinguish the voice.

sp.speaker: Iane.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I cann't speak for laughing— dear hony Madam, let me but go in and put on a couple o' Patches; you cann't imagine how much prettier I look with a Lozenge under the Left Eye, and a Half Moon o' this cheek; and then I'le but slip on the Silver-lac'd Shoes that you gave me, and be with him in a trice.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Don't stay, he's a fantastical fellow, if the whimsey take him he'l be gone. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lucia.
sp.l: They say he's to pass instantly this way
To lead his Bride to Church; ingrateful Man!
I'l stand here to upbraid his guilty Conscience,
And in that black attire in which he saw me
When he spoke the last kind words to me;
'Twill now befit my sorrows, and the Widow-hood of my Love;
He comes alone, what can that mean?

sp.speaker: Trum.
sp.l: Come, Madam, the Priest stays for us too long;
I ask your pardon for my dull delay,
And am asham'd of 't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What does he mean? I'l go with him what e'er it mean.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: Come to my bed, my dear, my dear, Sings.
My dear come to my bed,
For the pleasant pain, and the loss with gain
Is the loss of a Maidenhead.
For the pleasant, &c.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.l: Is that a Psalm, Brother Husband, which you sing?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.l: No, Sister Wife, a short Ejaculation onely.
Well said, Boy, bring in the things,— Boy brings a Hat and Feather, Sword and Belt, broad Lac'd Band, and Periwig.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: What do you mean, Brother Abednego? you will not turn Cavalier, I hope, again, you will not open before Sion in the dressings of Babylon?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: What do these cloathes befit Queen Tabitha's husband upon her day o' Nuptials? this Hat with a high black chimney for a crown, and a brim no broader than a Hatband? Shall I, who am to ride the Purple Dromedary, go drest like Revelation Fat's the Basket-maker? Give me the Peruique, Boy; shall Empress Tabitha's husband go as if his head were scalded? or wear the Seam of a shirt here for a a Band? Shall I who am zealous even to slaying, walk in the streets without a Sword, and not dare to thrust men from the wall, if any shall presume to take't of Empress Tabitha? Are the Fidlers coming, Boy?

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Pish, I cannot abide these doings; are you mad? there come no prophane Fidlers here.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Be peaceable gentle Tabitha; they will not bring the Organs with them hither; I say be peaceable, and conform to Revelations; It was the Vision bad me do this; Wil't thou resist the Vision?

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: An' these be your Visions? little did I think I wusse— O what shall I do? is this your Conversion? which of all the Prophets wore such a Map about their Ears, or such a Sheet about their Necks? Oh! my Mother! what shall I do? I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: VVhat shalt thou do? why, thou shalt Dance, and Sing, and Drink, and be Merry; thou shalt go with thy Hair Curl'd, and thy Brests Open; thou shalt wear fine black Stars upon thy Face, and Bobs in thy Ears bigger than bouncing Pears; Nay, if thou do'st begin but to look rustily— I'l ha' thee Paint thy self, like the VVhore o' Babylon.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Oh! that ever I was Born to see this day—

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: What, dost thou weep, Queen Dido? thou shalt ha' Sack to drive away thy Sorrows; bring in the Bottle, Boy, I'l be a Loving Husband, the Vision must be Obey'd; Sing Tabitha; Weep o'thy Wedding day? 'tis ominous; Come to my Bed my Dear, &c. Oh, art thou come Boy? fill a Brimmer, nay, fuller yet, yet a little fuller! Here Lady Spouse, here's to our sport at Night.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Drink it your self, an you will; I'l not touch it, not I.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: By this hand thou shal't pledge me, seeing the Vision said so; Drink, or I'l take a Coach, and carry thee to the Opera immediately.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Oh Lord, I can't abide it— Drinks off.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why, this will chear thy Heart; Sack, and a Husband? both comfortable things; have at you agen.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I'l pledge you no more, not I.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Here take the Glass, and take it off— off every drop, or I'l swear a hundred Oaths in a breathing time.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Well! you'r the strangest man— Drink.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why, this is right; nay, off with't; so— but the Vision said, that if we left our Drink behind us we should be Hang'd, as many other Honest men na'been, only by a little negligence in the like case; Here's to you Tabitha once agen, we must fulfill the Vision to a Tittle.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: What must I drink agen? well! you are such another Brother— Husband.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Bravely done, Tabitha! now thou Obey'st the Vision, thou wil't ha' Revelations presently.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Oh! Lord! my Head's giddy— nay, Brother, Husband, the Boy's taking away the Bottle, and there's another Glass or two in it still.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: O Villainous Boy! fill out you Bastard, and squeeze out the last drop.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: I'l drink to you now, my Dear; 'tis not handsome for you to begin always— Come to my Bed my Drinks. Dear, and how wast? 'twas a pretty Song, methoughts.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: O Divine Tabitha! here come the Fidlers too, strike up ye Rogues.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: What must we Dance too? is that the Fashion? I could ha' Danc'd the Curranto when I was a Girl, the Curranto's a curious Dance.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: We'l out-dance the Dancing disease; but Tabitha, there's one poor Health left still to be drunk with Musique.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Let me begin't; here Duck, here's to all that Drinks. Love us.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: A Health, ye Eternal Scrapers, sound a Health; rarely done Tabitha, what think'st thou now o' thy Mother?

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: A fig for my Mother; I'l be a Mother my self shortly; Come Duckling, shall we go home?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Go home? the Bride-groom and his Spouse go home? no, we'l Dance home; afore us Squeakers, that way, and be Hang'd you Sempiternal Rakers. O brave! Queen Tabitha! Excellent Empress Tabitha, on ye Rogues. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: But where's my what dee ye call her, Brother?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p:
My Daughter— Lucia, a pretty fair Complexioned Reads. Girl, with a Black Eye, a Round Chin, a
little Dimpled, and a Mole upon— I would fain see my Daughter— Brother.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: VVhy, you shall Sir presently, she's very well; what Noise is that? how now? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Ho! my old Master! my old Masters come, he's Lighted just now at the door with his man Iohn; he's asking for you, he longs to see you; my Master, my old Master.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: This fellows Mad.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: If you wo'nt believe me, go but in and see Sir; he's not so much alter'd, but you'l quickly know him, I knew him before he was Lighted, pray, go in Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: VVhy, this is strange— there was indeed some weeks since a report at the Exchange that he was Alive still, which was brought by a Ship that came from Barbary; but that he should be Split in two after his Death, and Live agen in both, is wonderfull to me. I'l go see what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I begin to shake like a Plum-tree Leaf.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: 'Tis a meer Plot o' the Devils to have us beaten, if he send him in just at this Nick.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter Ralph (as John) and two or three Servants.

sp.speaker: 1. Serv.
sp.p: Ah Rogue, art thou come at last?

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p: Why, you'l not look upon your Old friends! give me your Golls, Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: Thank ye all heartily for your Love; thank you with all my Heart; my old Bed-fellow, Robin, and how does little Ginny do?

sp.speaker: 3. Serv.
sp.p: A murren take you, you'l ne're leave your Waggery.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: A murren take ye all, I shall be paid the Portion here with a witness.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: And how does Ralph? good honest Ralph; there is not an honester Fellow in Christendome, though I say't my self, that should not say't.

sp.speaker: 2. Serv.
sp.p:
Ha, ha, ha! Why Ralph the Rogue's well still; Come
let's go to him into the Buttery, he'l be Over-joy'd to see thee, and give us a Cup o' the best Stingo there.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: VVell said; Steel to the back still Robin; that was your word you know; my Masters coming in! go, go, I'l follow you.

sp.speaker: 1 Serv.
sp.p: Make haste, good Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: Here's a Company of as honest Fellow-servants; I'm glad, I'm come among 'em agen.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: And would I were got out from 'em, as honest as they are; that Robin has a thrashing hand.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Iohn with a Pox to him! would I were hid like a Maggot in a Pescod.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Me-thinks you'r not return'd, but born to us anew.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Thank you good Brother; truly we ha' past through many dangers; my man Iohn shall tell you all, I'm Old and Crazie.

sp.speaker: 4 Serv.
sp.p: Sir, the VViddow (my Mistriss I should say) is coming in here with Mr. Knock-down, and four or five more.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: O'ds my Life! this farce is neither of Doctrine nor Use to them! keep 'em here, Iohn, till I come back.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I'm glad the Colonel's gone; now will I sneak away, as if I had stoln a Silver spoon.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: VVho are those, Iohn? by your leave Sir, would you speak with any body here?

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: The Colonel, Sir? but I'l take some other time to wait upon him, my occasions call me now.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Pray stay, Sir, who did you say you would ha' spoken with?

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: The Colonel, Sir; but another time will serve; he has business now.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: VVhom would he speak with, Iohn? I forget still.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: The Colonel, Sir.

sp.speaker: VVill.
sp.p: Colonel! what Colonel?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Your brother, I suppose he is Sir, but another time—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed; I had forgot, I faith, my Brother was a Colonel; I cry you mercy Sir, he'l be here presently. Ye seem to be Foreiners by your habits Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: No Sir, we are English-men.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: English-men? law you there now! would you ha' spoke with me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: No Sir, your Brother; but my business requires no haste, and therefore—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: You'r not in haste, you say; pray Sir, sit down then, may I crave your name, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: My name's not worth the knowing Sir—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: This Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: 'Tis my man, Sir, his name's Iohn.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I'l be Iohn no more, not I, I'l be Iackanapes first; No, my name's Timothy Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Mr. Iohn Timothy, very well, Sir; ye seem to be Travellers.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: We are just now as you see, arriv'd out of Afrique, Sir, and therefore have some business that requires—

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Of Afrique? law ye there now; what Country, pray?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Prester-Iohn's Country; fare you well, Sir, for the present, I must be excus'd.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Marry God forbid; what come from Prester-Iohn, and we not Drink a Cup o' Sack together.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: What shall I do? Friend, shall I trouble you to shew me a private place? I'l wait upon you presently agen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: You'l stay here Master?—

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I'l only make a little Maids water Sir, and come back to you immediately.

sp.speaker: Ral.
sp.p: The door's lock'd Sir, the Colonel ha's lock'd us in here— why do you shake Sir?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.l: Nothing— only I have extreme list to make water.
Here's the Colonel, I'l sneak behind the Hangings.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: We'l leave those Gentlemen within a while upon the point of Reprobation; but Sweet heart, I ha' two Brothers here, newly arriv'd, which you must be acquainted with.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marry, Heaven fore-shield! not the Merchant I hope?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: No, brethren in Love, only— How dee you Brother?

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I your Brother; what de'e mean?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Why, are not you my brother Iolly, that was taken Prisoner by the Southern Tartars?

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: I Brother, I by Tartars?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: What an impudent Slave is this? Sirra, Monster, did'st thou not come with thy man Iohn?

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: I my man Iohn? here's no such person here; you see you'r mistaken.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Sirra, I'l strike thee Dead.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir, I do remember now I was the Merchant Iolly, but when you ask'd me I had quite forgot it; alas, I'm very Crasie.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: That's not amiss; but since thou art not he, I must know who thou art.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: Why, do'nt you know me? I'm Captain VVorm, and Puny was my man Iohn.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Where's the fool, Puny? is he slipt away?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Yes, and no fool for't neither for ought I know yet.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: Why, we hit upon this frolique, Colonel, only for a kind o' Mask (de'ye conceive me, Colonel?) to celebrate your Nuptials; Mr. Puny had a mind to reconcile himself with you in a merry way o' Drollery, and so had I too, though I hope you were not in earnest with me.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Oh! is that all? well said VVill, bravely done VVill, I faith; I told thee, VVill, what 'twas to have Acted a Bear; and Ralph was an excellent Iohn too.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: How's this? then I'm an Ass agen; this damn'd Punies fearfulness spoil'd all.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: This cursed Coward VVorm! I thought they were not the right ones.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Here's something for you to drink; go look to Supper, this is your Cue or Exit. Ex. Will & Ralph.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: What need you, Love, ha' given 'em any thing? in truth, Love, 〈◊〉 ' too lavish.

sp.speaker: VVor.
sp.p: 'Twas wittily put off o' me however.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Here are more Maskers too, I think; this Masking is a Heavenly entertainment for the Widow, who ne'er saw any Shew yet but the Puppet-play o' Ninive.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Stay without, Scrapers.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Oh Lord, I'm as weary with Dancing as passes; Husband, husband, yonder's my Mother; O mother what do you think I ha' been doing to day?

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: Why what, Child? no hurt, I hope.

sp.speaker: Tab.
sp.p: Nay nothing, I have onely been married a little, and my husband Abednego and I have so danc'd it since.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Brave Tabitha still; never be angry Mother, you know where Marriages are made, your Daughters and your own were made in the same place, I warrant you, they'r so like.

sp.speaker: VVid.
sp.p: VVell, his will be done— there's— no resisting Providence— but how, son Abednego, come you into that roaring habit of Perdition?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Mother, I was commanded by the Vision, there is some great end for it of Edification, which you shall know by the sequel.

div.head: Scene 12.
div.stage: Enter Truman senior, Truman junior, Lucia veil'd.

sp.speaker: Trum. sen.
sp.p: Come, Dick, bring in your wife to your t'other father, and ask him blessing handsomely;
sp.l: Welcome, dear daughter; off with your Veil; Luc. unveils.
Heaven bless ye both.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Ha! what's this? more masking? why how now, Mr. Truman? you ha' not married my Niece, I hope, instead o' my daughter?

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: I onely did, Sir, as I was appointed,
And am amaz'd as much as you.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.l: Villain, Rebel, Traitor, out o' my sight you son of a—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Nay, hold him; patience, good Mr. Truman, let's understand the matter a little—

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: I wo'not understand, no that I wo'not, I wo'not understand a word, whilst he and his Whore are in my fight.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Nay, good Sir— Why, what Niece? two husbands in one afternoon? that's too much o' conscience.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Two, Sir? I know of none but this,
And how I came by him too, that I know not.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.l: This is Ridle me ridle me— where's my Daughter? ho! Aurelia.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Here, Sir, I was just coming in.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Ha' not you married young Mr. Truman?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Why, who then has he marri'd?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.l: Nay that, Sir, he may answer for himself,
If he be of age to marry.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: But did not you promise me you'd marry him this afternoon, and go to Church with him presently to do't?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: But, Sir, my Husband forbad the Banes.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: They're all mad; your Husband?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I Sir, the truth o' the matter, Sir, is this, (for it must out I see) 'twas I that was married this afternoon in the Matted Chamber to Mr. Puny, instead o' my Cousin Lucia.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Stranger and stranger! what, and he not know't?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: No, nor the Parson, Sir, himself.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Hey day!

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p:
'Twas done in the dark, Sir, and I veil'd like my Cousin; 'twas a very clandestine marriage, I confess, but there are sufficient
proofs of it; and for one, here's half the Piece of Gold he broke with me, which he'l know when he sees.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: O rare, by Hymen I'm glad o'the change; 'tis a pretty Sorceress by my troath; Wit to Wit quoth the Devil to the Lawyer; I'l out amongst 'em presently, 't has sav'd me a beating too, which perhaps is all her Portion.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: You turn my Head, you dizzie me; but wouldst thou marrie him without either knowing my mind, or so much as his?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: His, Sir? he gave me five hundred pieces in Gold to make the Match; look, they are here still, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Thou hast lost thy senses, VVench, and wilt make me do so too.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Briefly the truth is this, Sir, he gave me these five hundred Pieces to marry him by a Trick to my Cousin Lucia, and by another Trick I took the money and married him my self; the manner, Sir, you shall know anon at leisure, onely your pardon, Sir, for the omission of my duty to you, I beg upon my knees.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Nay, Wench, there's no hurt done, fifteen hundred pounds a year is no ill match for the daughter of a Sequestred Cavalier—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: I thought so, Sir.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: If we could but cure him of some sottish affectations, but that must be thy task.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: My life on't, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I'l out; Uncle Father your Blessing— my little Matchivil, I knew well enough 'twas you; what did you think I knew not Cross from Pile?

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Did you i'faith?

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: I by this kiss of Amber-grees, or I'm a Cabbage.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: Why then you out-witted me, and I'm content.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: A pox upon you Merchant Iolly, are you there?

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: But stay, how come you, Niece, to be marri'd to Mr. Truman?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know not, Sir, as I was walking in the Garden.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: I thought 'thad been— but blest be the mistake,
What ever prove the Consequence to all
The less important fortunes of my life.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Nay, there's no hurt done here neither—

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: No hurt, Colonel? I'l see him hang'd at my door before he shall have a beggarly—

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Hark you, Mr. Truman, one word aside Talk aside. (for it is not necessary yet my wife should know so much.)

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: This foolish Iane (as I perceive by the story) has lost a Husband by staying for a Black patch.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Though I in rigour by my brothers Will might claim the forfeiture of her Estate, yet I assure you she shall have it all to the utmost farthing; in a day like this, when Heaven bestows on me and on my daughter so unexpected and so fair a fortune, it were an ill return to rob an Orphan committed to my Charge.

sp.speaker: Aur
sp.l: My father's in the right.
And as he clears her Fortune, so will I
Her Honor. Hark you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: Why you speak, Sir, like a Vertuous Noble Gentleman, and do just as I should do my self in the same case; it is—

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: 'Twas I upon my credit in a Veil; to Trum. jun. I'l tell, if you please, all that you said, when you had read the Letter. But d' you hear, Mr. Truman, do not you believe now that I had a design to lie with you (if you had consented to my coming at mid-night) for upon my faith I had not, bud did it purely to try upon what terms your two Romantique Loves stood.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! but your Farce was not right me-thinks at the end.

sp.speaker: Pun.
sp.p: Why how, pray?

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: Why there should ha' been a Beating, a lusty Cudgeling to make it come off smartly with a twang at the tail.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: Say you so? h'as got a set of damnable brawny Servingmen.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: At least Iohn Pudding here should ha' been basted.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: A curse upon him, he sav'd himself like a Rat behind the Hangings.

sp.speaker: Trum. j.
sp.l: O Lucia, how shall I beg thy pardon
For my unjust suspitions of thy Virtue?
Can you forgive a very Repentant sinner?
VVill a whole life of Penitence absolve me?

sp.speaker: Trum. s.
sp.p: 'Tis enough, good noble Colonel, I'm satisfi'd; Come, Dick, I see 'twas Heavens will, and she's a very worthy virtuous Gentlewoman; I'm old and testy, but 'tis quickly over; my blessing upon you both.

sp.speaker: Cut.
sp.p: VVhy so, all's well of all sides then; let me see, here's a brave Coupling day, onely poor VVorm must lead a Monkish life of 't.

sp.speaker: Aur:
sp.p: I'l have a VVife for him too, if you will, fine Mrs. Iane within; I'le undertake for her, I ha' set her a gog aside. to day for a husband, the first comer has her sure.

sp.speaker: Wor.
sp.p: I, but what Portion has she, Mrs. Puny? for we Captains o' the King's side ha' no need o' VVives with nothing.

sp.speaker: Aur.
sp.p: VVhy Lozenges, and Half-moons, and a pair of Silver-lac'd Shoes; but that Tropes lost to you; well, we'l see among us what may be done for her.

sp.speaker: Ioll.
sp.p: Come, let's go in to Supper; there never was such a day of Intrigues as this in one Family. If my true Brother had come in at last too after his being five years dead, 'twould ha' been a very Play.

div.head: EPILOGUE, Spoken by CUTTER.
div.l: ME-thinks a Vision bids me silence break, Without his Peruique.
And some words to this Congregation speak,
So great and gay a one I ne'er did meet
At the Fifth Monarch's Court in Coleman-street.
But yet I wonder much not to espy a
Brother in all this Court call'd Zephaniah.
Bless me! where are we? What may this place be?
For I begin by Vision now to see
That this is a meer Theater; well then,
If't be e'en so, I'l Cutter be again. Puts on his Peruique.
Not Cutter the pretended Cavaleer,
For to confess ingenuously here
To you who always of that Party were,
I never was of any; up and down
I rowld, a very Rakehell of this Town.
But now my Follies and my Faults are ended,
My Fortune and my Mind are both amended,
And if we may believe one who has fail'd before,
Our Author says He'l mend, that is, He'l write no more.

div.head: EPILOGUE, At Court.
div.l: THe Madness of your People, and the Rage,
You've seen too long upon the Publique Stage,
'Tis time at last (great Sir) 'tis time to see
Their Tragique Follies brought to Comedy.
If any blame the Lowness of our Scene,
We humbly think some Persons there have been
On the Worlds Theatre not long ago,
Much more too High, than here they are too Low.
And well we know that Comedy of old,
Did her Plebeian rank with so much Honour hold,
That it appear'd not then too Base or Light,
For the Great Scipio's Conquering hand to Write.
How e're, if such mean Persons seem too rude,
When into Royal presence they intrude,
Yet we shall hope a pardon to receive
From you, a Prince so practis'd to forgive;
A Prince, who with th' applause of Earth and Heaven,
The rudeness of the Vulgar has Forgiven.
